item.title: I feel sorry for fellow students
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“baddy351, post:20, topic:410418”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=511703.msg3713622#msg3713622 date=1313500560]
During college i wrote one single application, and it allowed me to pass all 3 of our Java courses in one morning, leaving room for more intellectually challenging courses. I suggest you do something like that!
[/quote]
What did that application do?[/quote]It was a simple 2d rpg game with procedurally generated dungeons, not unlike nethack and other dungeon crawlers

item.title: I feel sorry for fellow students
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

in my uni…they wrote a program to go through the source code and try to optimize it, other than that they had a TA look over about 300 students source code just to make sure. Also if the optimization program optimize majority of the code, lets say more than 30%…you either re-code it or fail.
@^ i took turing & java in HS and barely learned anything, but i took C & C++ at uni, thats where my love for programing grew, specially due to C++ and OOP. Now i am drunk on Matlab [woot matlab rocks]

Read full topic
item.source: I feel sorry for fellow students

item.title: I feel sorry for fellow students
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

it maybe a little better than my college. this is what i go to school everyday(8 am to 2 pm, with a strict dress code) for. teacher walks in “whos here?” blah blah “ok. i want u guys to do this and this by the end of the hour. you guys know my number if u have any question, u can call/txt me, or look it up on google.” so basically we pay $20,000 to do what we can do from home to get an a.a.s. ive actually learned some stuff but its not like i wanted. Im the top of my class b/c i started learning programming in high school, and i guess all my other classmates have had little to no experience with programming.

Read full topic

item.title: I feel sorry for fellow students
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:7, topic:410418”][code=java]
public class OutputFive {
//The output of this program is to print the number 5. If it prints the number 5, the code is correct.

public static void main(String[] args) {
int i = 0;
i++;
i++;
i++;
i++;
i++;
System.out.println("Output is: " + i);
}
}[/code][/quote]

Kind of yeah. I skipped the first Java class (tested out, thank god). From my friends that were in that class, he actually did want them to use a for-loop to count to 10. He doesn’t actually look at the source code. He wants us to take a screenshot of the program output and send it to him in a word file. So, here’s what the students did: (NOTE: I did actually ask on of the students for their work)

int output = 0;
for (int number = 0; number <= 10; number = number + 1) {
    output = number;
}
System.out.println(output);

…

Read full topic

item.title: I feel sorry for fellow students
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

The Reaper X:

Have you considered the fact that lesson plans teach things according to how easy you can grasp the lesson? I’ve taken courses that teach the worst way possible and when I approached the teacher about it he said that he uses shitty techniques so that students understand the concept and functionality with the most basic features the language holds. He’s a pretty cool guy actually, and I’m gonna guess that’s what’s happening there.

The teacher isn’t the one who wrote it. It’s some other guy “Liang” or something who has a book, and the school pays him thousands to use his material.

Although, I forgot that I did edit the code. The lesson was on multithreaded applications. This was the Homework/Project code. The teacher said that to get an A was to change the square (which is what was drawn by default) into a circle. No need to change the code other than that. Or, as he likes to put it

If the output of the program is correct, then the program must be as well.

Read full topic
item.source: I feel sorry for fellow students

item.title: I feel sorry for fellow students
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

The Reaper X:

Have you considered the fact that lesson plans teach things according to how easy you can grasp the lesson? I’ve taken courses that teach the worst way possible and when I approached the teacher about it he said that he uses shitty techniques so that students understand the concept and functionality with the most basic features the language holds. He’s a pretty cool guy actually, and I’m gonna guess that’s what’s happening there.

Very true.

When you have optimized code it can make it much harder to read. When I was taking design concepts (stupid class imo) we had to learn basic HTML (ouch, I had my own tool written for this, while they used DreamWeaver). Needless to say, the teacher taught the most horrifying way to style a page, using a new CSS per page, instead of making a CSS for parts of the page. This was just so the other students could grasp the ‘coding’, as she called it, easier.

Read full topic

item.title: I feel sorry for fellow students
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

This is just one example of the quality of the programs my school is paying thousands of dollars for, and the fellow students are supposed to benefit from.

NOTE: I did not change any of this code

package unit3;

import java.util.*;
import java.awt.*;
import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.event.*;
import java.util.concurrent.locks.*;

public class Exercise29_6 extends JApplet {
    public static boolean circle = true;
  public Exercise29_6() {
    add(new BallControlUsingThread());
  }

  /** Main method */
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    JFrame frame = new JFrame();
    JApplet applet = new Exercise29_6();
    frame.add(applet);
    frame.setTitle("Exercise29_6");
    frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null); // Center the frame
    frame.setSize(400, 200);
    frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
    frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null); // Center the frame
    frame.setVisible(true);
  }

  class BallControlUsingThread extends JPanel implements ActionListener,
    AdjustmentListener {
    private Ball ball = new Ball();
    private JButton jbtSuspend = new JButton("Suspend");
    private JButton jbtResume = new JButton("Resume");
    private JButton jbtAdd = new JButton("+1");
    private JButton jbtSubtract = new JButton("-1");
    private JScrollBar jsbDelay = new JScrollBar();

    public BallControlUsingThread() {
      // Group buttons in a panel
      JPanel panel = new JPanel();
      panel.add(jbtSuspend);
      panel.add(jbtResume);
      panel.add(jbtAdd);
      panel.add(jbtSubtract);

      // Add ball and buttons to the panel
      ball.setBorder(new javax.swing.border.LineBorder(Color.red));
      jsbDelay.setOrientation(JScrollBar.HORIZONTAL);
      ball.setDelay(jsbDelay.getMaximum());
      setLayout(new BorderLayout());
      add(jsbDelay, BorderLayout.NORTH);
      add(ball, BorderLayout.CENTER);
      add(panel, BorderLayout.SOUTH);

      // Register listeners
      jbtSuspend.addActionListener(this);
      jbtResume.addActionListener(this);
      jbtAdd.addActionListener(this);
      jbtSubtract.addActionListener(this);
      jsbDelay.addAdjustmentListener(this);
    }

    public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
      if (e.getSource() == jbtSuspend) {
        ball.suspend();
      }
      else if (e.getSource() == jbtResume) {
        ball.resume();
      }
      else if (e.getSource() == jbtAdd) {
        ball.add();
      }
      else if (e.getSource() == jbtSubtract) {
        ball.subtract();
      }

    }

    public void adjustmentValueChanged(AdjustmentEvent e) {
      ball.setDelay(jsbDelay.getMaximum() - e.getValue());
    }

    class Ball extends JPanel implements Runnable {
      private int speed = 10;

      // Create a timer with delay 1000 ms
      protected Thread timer = new Thread(this);

      private ArrayList list = new ArrayList();

      private int x = 0;
      private int y = 0; // Current ball position

      private int radius = 5; // Ball radius
      private int dx = 2; // Increment on ball's x-coordinate
      private int dy = 2; // Increment on ball's y-coordinate

      public Ball() {
        timer.start();
      }

      public void add() {
        list.add(new BallState());
      }

      public void subtract() {
        if (list.size() > 0) {
          list.remove(list.size() - 1); // Remove the last one
        }
      }

      protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        super.paintComponent(g);

        g.setColor(Color.red);

        for (int i = 0; i < list.size(); i++) {
          BallState ball = (BallState)list.get(i);

          // Check boundaries
          if (ball.x < radius) {
            ball.dx = Math.abs(ball.dx);
          }
          if (ball.x > getWidth() - radius) {
            ball.dx = -Math.abs(ball.dx);
          }
          if (ball.y < radius) {
            ball.dy = Math.abs(ball.dy);
          }
          if (ball.y > getHeight() - radius) {
            ball.dy = -Math.abs(ball.dy);
          }

          // Adjust ball position
          ball.x += ball.dx;
          ball.y += ball.dy;
          if (circle) {
              g.fillOval(ball.x - radius, ball.y - radius, radius * 2, radius * 2);
          }
          else {
              g.fillRect(ball.x - radius, ball.y - radius, radius, radius);
          }
          circle = !circle;
        }
      }

      boolean isSuspended = false;
      Lock lock = new ReentrantLock();
      Condition suspended = lock.newCondition();

      public void run() {
        try {
          while (true) {
            repaint();
            Thread.sleep(speed);
            while (isSuspended) {
              lock.lock();
              suspended.await();
              lock.unlock();
            }
          }
        }
        catch (Exception ex) {
          ex.printStackTrace();
        }
      }

      public void resume() {
        lock.lock();
        isSuspended = false;
        suspended.signalAll();
        lock.unlock();
      }

      public void suspend() {
        lock.lock();
        isSuspended = true;
        lock.unlock();
      }

      public void setDelay(int ms) {
        speed = ms;
      }

      class BallState {
        int x = 0;
        int y = 0; // Current ball position
        int dx = 2; // Increment on ball's x-coordinate
        int dy = 2; // Increment on ball's y-coordinate

        public BallState() {
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

I have seriously seen some of the worst programmers on MSCP create better programs than this. If I didn’t have Java experience prior to going to college, I’m sure I would be fucked.

EDIT: And yes, each new “ball” is it’s own thread.

Read full topic
